metadata.case_name: Andhra Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: Andhra Insurance Company Ltd. carried on life insurance and other insurance business.
On September 1, 1956, the life insurance business of the insurer became vested in the Life Insurance Corporation of India under the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956.
Insurer became entitled to compensation from LIC under s.16 of the Act.
Life Insurance Tribunal constituted on May 25, 1957.

On February 19, 1957 (or February 14, 1957), Corporation determined compensation amount of Rs. 6,14,636 approved by Central Government and offered it to insurer, claiming deductions of Rs. 3,76,117 for assets not transferred.
Insurer raised disputes over deductions; correspondence ensued, accepted computation but disputed asset valuation.
On August 6, 1957, insurer made application to Tribunal for re-assessment of compensation and prayed for extension of time by three months from Tribunal's constitution.
On September 21, 1957, insurer filed statement giving details of claim.
Corporation filed written statement resisting claim.

Tribunal by judgment dated February 17, 1958 held insurer had no right to approach Tribunal directly, had to move Corporation for reference, no cause shown for extension, claim time-barred under r.12; dismissed application.
Insurer obtained special leave from Supreme Court to appeal.
After leave granted, insurer amalgamated with Hindustan Ideal Insurance Co. Ltd., substituted as appellant on April 14, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether insurer has right to approach Tribunal directly for dispute on compensation or must move Corporation for reference under s.16(2).
Whether proceedings before Tribunal were time-barred under r.12 of Rules.
Interpretation of s.16(2) and r.12: who makes reference, prescription of time for insurer to move Corporation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Since Tribunal appointed after expiry of three months under r.12, limitation commences from date of constitution.
Fit case for extension of time under proviso to r.12.

respondent_arguments.text: Insurer cannot prefer claim directly to Tribunal; must move Corporation for reference within three months under s.16(2) and r.12.
Proceedings incompetent as no reference by Corporation.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.16(2), insurer has no right to approach Tribunal directly; must have matter referred through Corporation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Procedure contemplates insurer moves Corporation, Corporation refers dispute to Tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: Direct application to Tribunal wholly misconceived and incompetent; no relief possible.
r.12 does not prescribe time for insurer to move Corporation as required by s.16(2); proviso indicates reference by insurer/chief agent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No period prescribed for insurer to move Corporation; lacuna in rules.

court_reasoning.text: No question of limitation or extension arises as proceedings misconceived; insurer can move Corporation after prescription of period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inquiry into limitation irrelevant due to incompetence.

holdings.text: Insurer cannot approach Tribunal directly; reference must be through Corporation under s.16(2).
r.12 applies to reference by insurer, not Corporation; no prescription of time for moving Corporation.
Proceedings before Tribunal incompetent; no need to decide limitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: West Derby Union v. Metropolitan Life Assurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Proviso may throw light on ambiguous statutory words; useful guide to scope of enactment.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of business, entitlement to compensation, Tribunal constitution, reference procedure, rule-making power.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as proceedings before Tribunal were incompetent since insurer approached directly without reference by Corporation under s.16(2); no prescription of time for moving Corporation, but direct approach invalid. Appellant may move Corporation after period prescribed.
outcome.costs: No costs to respondent as it did not contend incompetence before Tribunal or in statement of case.

key_quotes.text: "An insurer has no right under the section to approach the Tribunal directly. The procedure contemplated is that an insurer has to move the Corporation and the Corporation has thereupon to refer the dispute raised by the insurer to the Tribunal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on procedure under s.16(2)

key_quotes.text: "The proceedings before the Tribunal were misconceived because the only way in which they could be initiated was by a reference by the Corporation and there was no such reference."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Prescribing time by implication would not be compliance with the provisions of sub-s.2 of s.16."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On interpretation of r.12 and lacuna
